data.title: DisplayMode.AspectRatio fix
data.body: DisplayMode.AspectRatio was always returning 1.0f because width and height are int, and weren't being cast to float for the division.

data.title: ResourceContentManager
data.body:
Copying the issue from CodePlex here

if you load content using a ResourceContentManager (From a DLL in my case, for my UI) and load normal content, the usual way. The ResourceContentManager loaded items disappear, such as fonts, and textures.

This can be reproduced, by taking a sample with the Game Debug Tools and loading the font from a ResourceContentManager. Takes about 20-30 seconds before issue occurs, or force GC and you will have the issue.

data.title: More PackedVector Fixes
data.body:
I fixed a bunch of bugs in the PackedVector types adding in unit tests as I went:
- NormalizedShort2/4 both had incorrect packing and unpacking.
- Bgra4444 didn't clamp input values.
- Bgra4444 wasn't swizzling to BGRA.
- Short4 wasn't packing correctly.
- Bgr565 wasn't doing input clamping.

These changes match XNA behavior 100%.

data.title: Floating Point Textures in OpenGL ES 2.0
data.body:
I am making the game based on a fluids interaction ([video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KnOwDzbFT3w)). It is very expensive to simulate so I have to use GPU instead of CPU. It works fine on MonoGamе for WindowsGL but I need to implement it on mobile devices. 

Unfortunately, there is a problem with floating-point textures: they aren’t supported in MonoGame for Android but are heavily used in the simulation. However, in `OpenTK.Graphics.ES20` there are constants like `OesTextureFloat` and `OesTextureHalfFloat` so OpenGL ES 2.0 implementation in OpenTK supports it (I hope). Also I have found that all modern devices support `OES_texture_half_float` and `OES_texture_float` extensions ([OpenGL ES 2.0 Extensions on Android Devices](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/3881197/opengl-es-2-0-extensions-on-android-devices)).

Thus, I think I can implement this feature in MonoGame (while I have never worked with OpenGL, only with Direct3D). I can start from this commit [Added support for all remaining SurfaceFormat values in OpenGL](https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/pull/1686) (thanks @KonajuGames for it).

I ask you to give me some roadmaps, ideas, notes, drafts, potential issues and so on, if you can.

data.title: Implemented NormalizedByte4/Byte2
data.body: Implementation of NormalizedByte4, NormalizedByte2, and tests to validate it.  This addresses issue #2171.

data.title: DX11.2/W8.1 Branch
data.body:
I would like to know if anyone is work on DX11.2 for monogame and manage to make it work with XAML/SwapChainBackgroundPanel.

So far, 
I used the "latest Dev Package (2.5.1)" (http://sharpdx.org/news/support-directx11-2) and move them into "MonoGame\ThirdParty\Libs\SharpDX\Windows 8.1 Metro".
Upgrade MonoGame and my Projects to Windows 8.1. 
Change some code in the GraphicsDevice.cs because SwapChain creation on sharpDX has changed.

from:
    _swapChain = dxgiFactory2.CreateSwapChainForComposition(_d3dDevice, ref desc, null);
into:
using (var comDevice = new ComObject(_d3dDevice))
                            _swapChain = new SwapChain1(dxgiFactory2, comDevice, ref desc, null);

When I try to create the SwapChain I get an Exception and the folowing error in the output: 

DXGI ERROR: IDXGIFactory::CreateSwapChain: DXGI_SWAP_EFFECT_FLIP_SEQUENTIAL is not supported on D3D10. D3D11 or later is required. [ MISCELLANEOUS ERROR #99: ]

Same behaviour on two systems, one with ATI DX 10.1 and the second with NVidia DX 9.1.
Both the sharpDX Sample and monogame seems to go through the same simple sequence of initilization. first create the Device, then the  SwapChain with identical parameters.

data.title: WP back button cancel fix
data.body: A quick fix to only fire back button events on Windows Phone if they weren't handled/fired yet. Useful if you want to use some silverlight UI elements to replace the standard Guide keyboard and message boxes for example.

data.title: [WP8] Game draining battery quick while thumbstoned
data.body: I noticed it on several lumia phones.

data.title: Added PassThroughProcessor.
data.body: Turns out we were missing the simplest processor XNA has. It's effectively a no-op.

data.title: Fix for Issue #2199
data.body: Previous ticks was not being reset.

data.title: ResetElapsedTime not working anymore.
data.body:
I suspect that 4115c990d64d9071053e07b70e813dcad4e916f2 and 8434136f1b6fff47db2fc1e3131d99e98a16cfae broke ResetElapsedTime method!
I saw unexpected behavior on Windows8.
I'm almost reverting this commits on my branch.
Can anybody confirm this? It's quite urgent...

data.title: Fixed Mouse Button State Issues
data.body:
Buttons would cancel each others ButtonState.Pressed  out, as well
rotating the mousewheel would cancel all ButtonState.Pressed.

Now the state of the three Buttons is manually set and removed on MouseDown and MouseUp, and monogames MouseState gets set appropriately

data.title: Regarding multiple contexts on the OpenGL backends
data.body:
I just came across an interesting post about OpenGL performance with multiple contexts: https://forums.libsdl.org/viewtopic.php?p=41512#41512

> Short version: 
> Never use shared contexts for performance-conscious code, it costs way more than > the failed (more on that later) overlap of the texture uploads. 
> 
> Long version: 
> During early development of a major product (Steam Big Picture Mode) in the past
> that used multiple contexts for background uploading of OpenGL textures, we were 
> told by multiple desktop GPU vendors that the drivers flatly mutex every OpenGL 
> call when you have shared contexts, this can result in major (~20%) fps loss even if
> you don't use the other context at all, it gets worse if you do, and in 
> particular the texture upload does NOT happen in parallel with rendering due to that
> mutexing.
> 
> So my advice is never do this, we changed the product to not do this before launch 
> because it was completely not performant, we had been struggling to keep up 60fps 
> until we did, then it easily exceeded 200fps with that one change.
> 
> [...]

Has anyone ever tested the impact (positive or negative) of using multiple contexts in the OpenGL backend of MonoGame? If the quoted performance numbers are valid, then this might lead to a significant performance improvement.

data.title: New GUIDs for Lidgren.Network.{Linux,MacOS}.csproj
data.body:
These two projects had the same GUID as Lidgren.Network.Windows.csproj
did, which caused trouble when trying to include them in the same
solution.

This gives the Linux and MacOS projects new GUIDs and updates the
solutions that include them to use the new GUID.

data.title: Fixed the drifting away of the GameTime
data.body:
Please see this issue:
https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/issues/2194

data.title: Gametime drifting away slowly
data.body:
When developing my network based game I encountered an issue that two clients had their gametime drifting away.
After some more research I found out that it can be easily reproduced by creating a new project and comparing the gameTime.TotalGameTime with a stopwatch.

You can see they drift apart slowly.

After some digging through the source I also found the fix for this issue, in the current Game class every Tick a new stopwatch is being created. This results in quite a significant loss of ticks (while generating and starting the new stopwatch).

I don't know how I can upload a patch to Github so if anyone can give me a hand here I would love to resolve this issue.

Edit:

I've created a pull request, see here:
https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/pull/2195

data.title: <Request> Anyone got a sample multiple platform controller?
data.body:
Finally got some time to re-visit the new samples and the platformer project is ready to go with one gap, a proper controller system that is multi-platform.

Does anyone have a sample or code they can share for a controller setup so I can avoid having to create one from scratch.

As this is for the samples it will need:
- A good abstracted setup
- Controller profiles for most / all platforms (Ouya gamepad, touch, accelerometer, keyboard, etc)
- Preferably with a configurable option to allow players to define their own control systems - A wish but not essential

hopefully we will then end up with a simple package that everyone will be able to use with MG going forward and probably end up as a NuGet package for easy use in the future.

Ideas? Suggestions? Samples?

data.title: [3.2 #296] Windows OpenGL template trying to use SharpDX?
data.body:
When I created a new Windows OpenGL project using MonoGame 3.2 #296 on VS2010 it didn't run because it apparently tried to use SharpDX in some way, giving me this error (translated by me since my .NET isn't on English):

```
Can't load type 'SharpDX.Win32.MessageFilterHook' from assembly 'SharpDX, Version=2.5.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=null'.
```

I just tried to run it right after creating the project. There's no problem with the Windows (DirectX) template. Version 3.0.1 OpenGL behaves properly.

data.title: Implemented "Garbage-Free" GraphicsDevice.GetRenderTargets
data.body:
Implemented property in GraphicsDevice to get the current Render Count
and overloaded GetRenderTargets to copy to an array you provide instead
of generating a new one (therefore, creating garbage).  Only problem is
that it is the user's responsibility to make sure the array they create
can fit the render contents or an exception will be thrown.

data.title: Bug 2079 - Implemented SetVibration for Windows8 as a method stub for co...
data.body: ...mpilation compatibility, and with VibrateController for WindowsPhone.

data.title: NuGet update release for 7th January
data.body:
- No Code changes
- Main NuGet package now depends on binaries release rather than duplicating references (will make it easier for projects using the full proj to just update binaries)
- Windows GL build now no longer crashes with Sharp DX errors

data.title: [ContentReaders] Allocate just the right amount of memory for Lists
data.body:
Allocate the exact amount of memory for list.
This makes the content loaders more memory efficient and also improves
performance by eliminating the need to perform resizing operations in
the case of big arrays (ex. models with skinnning data).

data.title: MonoGame NuGet package should depend on MonoGame.Binaries instead of duplicating the binaries
data.body: Basically, just remove everything from the build folder in the MonoGame NuGet package, and add a package dependency to MonoGame.Binaries.  That way other NuGet packages can depend just on MonoGame.Binaries, and they will work whether the developer originally installed the MonoGame or MonoGame.Binaries package.

data.title: FBX importer does not work
data.body:
We have tried FBX files with the following properties:
- 2014, binary format
- 2011, ASCII format
- with bones
- without bones
- with animations
- without animations

So far, none of these have imported successfully. There is a crash on line 201 of ModelReader:

```
                mesh.Name = name;
                mesh.ParentBone = bones[parentBoneIndex]; /// here
                mesh.ParentBone.AddMesh(mesh);
```

Because the parentBoneIndex is -1.  I modified the code to map based on the bone name instead of the index, which got past this point, but the model then half rendered and vertices were missing from the mesh.

Is there a specification on what forms of FBX are supported in the MonoGame content pipeline?

data.title: Add missing ranged transform overloads to Vector3
data.body: Add the two missing Vector3 Transform methods that work on a range of values within an array.  I opted not to implement the whole-array versions in terms of the ranged versions, due to the extra adds per vertex operation.

data.title: [WP8] ContentManager.Load<Texture2D>(string) throws NotImplementedException
data.body:
I have my DPSF library working fine using MonoGame on Android, IOS, and WinRT, but when I use the WP8 MonoGame.Framework assembly, it throws the following exception when I try running through the emulator:

```
System.NotImplementedException: The method or operation is not implemented.
   at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.Texture2D.FromStream(GraphicsDevice graphicsDevice, Stream stream)
   at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Content.ContentManager.ReadRawAsset[T](String assetName, String originalAssetName)
   at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Content.ContentManager.ReadAsset[T](String assetName, Action`1 recordDisposableObject)
   at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Content.ContentManager.Load[T](String assetName)
```

This exception is thrown by this line in my library:

```
mcTexture = ContentManager.Load<Texture2D>(sTexture);
```

where sTexture is just the string containing the name of the texture asset to load.

So it appears this method has not been implemented in the Windows Phone 8 MonoGame.Framework assembly yet.  Is this correct?  It's strange that I haven't been able to find anybody else complain about this problem, so either I'm not looking hard enough, or I'm doing something wrong.

This exception is thrown both when using the x86 and ARM versions of the WP8 MonoGame.Framework assembly.  I obtained both assemblies by compiling the develop branch; I just got latest and recompiled the assemblies today, and this problem is still present.

Any suggestions are appreciated.  Thanks.
